abstract:
Uncovering the neural dynamics of facial identity processing along with its representational basis
12 outlines a major endeavor in the study of visual processing. To this end, here we record human
13 electroencephalography (EEG) data associated with viewing face stimuli; then, we exploit spatiotemporal
14 EEG information to determine the neural correlates of facial identity representations and to reconstruct the
15 appearance of the corresponding stimuli. Our findings indicate that multiple temporal intervals support:
16 facial identity classification, face space estimation, visual feature extraction and image reconstruction. In
17 particular, we note that both classification and reconstruction accuracy peak in the proximity of the N170
18 component. Further, aggregate data from a larger interval (50-650 ms after stimulus onset) support robust
19 reconstruction results, consistent with the availability of distinct visual information over time. Thus,
20 theoretically, our findings shed light on the time course of face processing while, methodologically, they
21 demonstrate the feasibility of EEG-based image reconstruction.
